tools.description: Finds an email message.

instructions.description: Instructions for running this tool. Any parameters that are not given a value will be guessed based on the instructions.

query.description: This is a gmail query search. Examples of queries include specifying sender (from:amy), recipient (to:david), words in the subject line (subject:dinner), matching multiple terms (from:amy OR from:david), excluding terms (dinner -movie), searching for an exact word or phrase ("dinner and movie tonight"), attachments (has:attachment, filename:pdf), labels (label:friends), and time periods (after:YYYY-MM-DD, before:YYYY-MM-DD). Users can also search by categories (category:updates), message size (larger:10M), and more. When asked vaguely to return the last, latest, or any email from their inbox, use in:inbox to do the lookup.

And a reminder that swyx is hosting an hackathon with Karpathy, OpenAI, and the Cognition team this weekend, apply here!

"Self-Improving" is a scary term in AI safety; it has an undertone of "the machine will become smarter than us, in a way we don't understand". But what if we could understand it?

In Oct '24 OpenAI released MLE Bench, a benchmark that measures how well LLMs do at machine learning engineering. The self-improving trajectory through ML Engineering is driven by better algorithms, cleaner data, and more efficient memory usage: training-time self-improvement. But most AI Engineers do not train models, they are just users of them. How can they play a part? If you could never update the weights, how would you have the model increase its performance on a specific task? I think of that as inference-time self-improvement, with Voyager being one of the early approaches to this through its skill library.

Since I started working on Kernel Labs (more on that soon 👀), parallelizing coding agents with things like claude-squad and vibe-kanban has been one of the most effective productivity hacks. When Boris Cherny called Claude Code a “unix utility” in our interview, it really clicked for me. The most valuable use case of coding agents is being a vessel for LLMs to extract value out of their own latent spaces.

How do we optimize for that? Can models do it themselves? Since I got access to GPT-5, I spent the whole time playing around with this flow:

  • I started by asking the model to build a set of tools it thought would help it be more productive

  • Attempt a task using them, with me supervising it

  • After completion, self-reflect on how the tools could be improved

I also compared this to Opus 4 (4.1 was not out yet). The good news is that GPT-5 is a very good model for building developer utilities. The bad news is that it hates using the tools it creates! As it told me "I'll be honest - I didn't need an Content truncated. Call the fetch tool with a start_index of 5000 to get more content.

"Self-Improving" is a scary term in AI safety; it has an undertone of "the machine will become smarter than us, in a way we don't understand". But what if we could understand it?

In Oct '24 OpenAI released MLE Bench, a benchmark that measures how well LLMs do at machine learning engineering. The self-improving trajectory through ML Engineering is driven by better algorithms, cleaner data, and more efficient memory usage: training-time self-improvement. But most AI Engineers do not train models, they are just users of them. How can they play a part? If you could never update the weights, how would you have the model increase its performance on a specific task? I think of that as inference-time self-improvement, with Voyager being one of the early approaches to this through its skill library.

Since I started working on Kernel Labs (more on that soon 👀), parallelizing coding agents with things like claude-squad and vibe-kanban has been one of the most effective productivity hacks. When Boris Cherny called Claude Code a “unix utility” in our interview, it really clicked for me. The most valuable use case of coding agents is being a vessel for LLMs to extract value out of their own latent spaces.

How do we optimize for that? Can models do it themselves? Since I got access to GPT-5, I spent the whole time playing around with this flow:

  • I started by asking the model to build a set of tools it thought would help it be more productive

  • Attempt a task using them, with me supervising it

  • After completion, self-reflect on how the tools could be improved

I also compared this to Opus 4 (4.1 was not out yet). The good news is that GPT-5 is a very good model for building developer utilities. The bad news is that it hates using the tools it creates! And a reminder that swyx is hosting an hackathon with Karpathy, OpenAI, and the Cognition team this weekend, apply here!

"Self-Improving" is a scary term in AI safety; it has an undertone of "the machine will become smarter than us, in a way we don't understand". But what if we could understand it?

In Oct '24 OpenAI released MLE Bench, a benchmark that measures how well LLMs do at machine learning engineering. The self-improving trajectory through ML Engineering is driven by better algorithms, cleaner data, and more efficient memory usage: training-time self-improvement. But most AI Engineers do not train models, they are just users of them. How can they play a part? If you could never update the weights, how would you have the model increase its performance on a specific task? I think of that as inference-time self-improvement, with Voyager being one of the early approaches to this through its skill library.

Since I started working on Kernel Labs (more on that soon 👀), parallelizing coding agents with things like claude-squad and vibe-kanban has been one of the most effective productivity hacks. When Boris Cherny called Claude Code a “unix utility” in our interview, it really clicked for me. The most valuable use case of coding agents is being a vessel for LLMs to extract value out of their own latent spaces.

How do we optimize for that? Can models do it themselves? Since I got access to GPT-5, I spent the whole time playing around with this flow:

  • I started by asking the model to build a set of tools it thought would help it be more productive

  • Attempt a task using them, with me supervising it

  • After completion, self-reflect on how the tools could be improved

I also compared this to Opus 4 (4.1 was not out yet). The good news is that GPT-5 is a very good model for building developer utilities. The bad news is that it hates using the tools it creates! "Self-Improving" is a scary term in AI safety; it has an undertone of "the machine will become smarter than us, in a way we don't understand". But what if we could understand it?

In Oct '24 OpenAI released MLE Bench, a benchmark that measures how well LLMs do at machine learning engineering. The self-improving trajectory through ML Engineering is driven by better algorithms, cleaner data, and more efficient memory usage: training-time self-improvement. But most AI Engineers do not train models, they are just users of them. How can they play a part? If you could never update the weights, how would you have the model increase its performance on a specific task? I think of that as inference-time self-improvement, with Voyager being one of the early approaches to this through its skill library.

Since I started working on Kernel Labs (more on that soon 👀), parallelizing coding agents with things like claude-squad and vibe-kanban has been one of the most effective productivity hacks. When Boris Cherny called Claude Code a “unix utility” in our interview, it really clicked for me. The most valuable use case of coding agents is being a vessel for LLMs to extract value out of their own latent spaces.
